scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification has been included in a national catalogue from a Member State whose NIF is fully aligned with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to NIFO factsheets.
statement:
IPv6 is included in 4 national catalogues, which belong to Member States which comply with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to the NIFO factsheets.

See:                                                                                                                                               https://www.forumstandaardisatie.nl/open-standaarden/lijst
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

criterion_description: The standard or specification facilitates the publication of public data as open data.
statement: The specification is not related to the publication of public data as open data. Therefore this criterion is not applicable to this specification.

criterion_description: All stakeholders have the opportunity to contribute to the development of the specificationÂ
statement:
IETF has a formal review and approval so that all the relevant stakeholders can formally appeal or raise objections to the development and approval of specifications.

Each distinct version of an Internet standards-related specification is published as part of the "Request for Comments" (RFC) document series. This archival series is the official publication channel for Internet standards documents and other publications.

During the development of a specification, draft versions of the document are made available for informal review and comment by placing them in the IETF's "Internet-Drafts" directory, which is replicated on a number of Internet hosts. This makes an evolving working document readily available to a wide audience, facilitating the process of review and revision.

See:
https://www.ietf.org/standards/process/ 
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2026

criterion_description: The standard or specification is licensed on a (F)RAND basis
statement:
Like all the IETF standards, IPv6 is a free and open technical specification, built on IETF standards and licenses from the Open Web Foundation. IPv6 is therefore licensed on a royalty-free basis.
No IPR disclosures have been submitted directly on the IPv6 specification (RFC 2818).
See:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3668

criterion_description: The standard or specification is sufficiently mature and has sufficient market acceptance for its use in the development of products and services.
statement:
The IPv6 has a 25% of share in internet-connected network advertise. 49 country report 5% of the traffic through IPv6 and 24 countries exceed the 15%.
See:
https://www.internetsociety.org/resources/2018/state-of-ipv6-deployment-2018/

criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters the creation of innovative solutions.
statement:
IPv6 is an extensible protocol open to new needs. It can develop together with new advanced application like: P2P, GRID, Ambient Intelligence.
See:
https://www.nro.net/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/ipv6_is_an_innovation_opportunity.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification has a strong support from at least one developer community.
statement:
IPv6 is maintained and developed by IETF which is an international community developing open standards
Moreover, the deployment of IPv6 is rapidly expanding in the Internet. Support for IPv6 in applications is lagging behind and endorse such as Apple are taking steps to rectify this situation and raise awareness to the problem.

See: 
https://www.ietf.org/about/ 
https://community.cisco.com/t5/jive-developer-archive-documents/ipv6-for-application-developers-whitepaper/ta-p/3647032

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters the visibility and comprehensibility of administrative rules, processes, data, services and decision-making of a public administration.
statement:
As Internet Protocol Stack, IPv6 it is being selected gradually by different Member States. The specification is the most used for the data exchange over the internet therefore IPv6 fosters the visibility of data across borders. 

The European Union is willing to implement the IPV6 as state on the following report: "The adoption of IPv6 in Europe, in particular within European public administrations, is still low, but the availability of IPv6 communication is vital for the economic development and the digitisation of European public administrations. The goals of the Digital Agenda for Europe and the Digital Single Market Strategy are based on stable and reliable data networks."
See: https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/sites/isa/files/ipv6_framework_for_european_governments_0.pdf

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification helps ensuring the availability of interfaces with internal information systems of a public administration.
statement:
The European Union considers the IPv6 as very important to "ensure the cross-border interoperability of online services and the digitisation of European public
administrations for the ISA2 goals"
See: https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/sites/isa/files/ipv6_framework_for_european_governments_0.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification is reusable beyond the domain for which it was originally developed.Â
statement: IPv6 is a business domain agnostic specification.

criterion_description: The standard has been made available for its reuse by the organisations, administrations, open communities, etc. that developed it.
statement:
The European Union promotes the usage of IPv6 and the public administration are able to reuse it.  "MS as for instance Germany could bring strong support to the deployment of IPv6 within the European public administrations." 
Source: https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/sites/isa/files/ipv6_framework_for_european_governments_0.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification is independent from any specific technology and/or platform.
statement: The specification purpose is to enable communications over the internet. IPv6 is the new version of IPv4 which is a widely used protocol therefore it is not dependent of any specific platform or technology. Thus, the adoption of IPv6 does not hamper the interoperability.

The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is proportionate to the needs of its users (citizens, businesses or administrations).
statement:
IPv6 as a protocol with objective of enhancing communications over a computer network, allows the scalability of systems. 
Moreover, the European Union promotes the usage of IPv6 and the public administration are able to reuse it.  "MS as for instance Germany could bring strong support to the deployment of IPv6 within the European public administrations." 
Source: https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/sites/isa/files/ipv6_framework_for_european_governments_0.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters data portability between systems and applications supporting the implementation and evolution of European public services when legally possible.
statement:
IPv6 allows data exchange between systems and it is compatible with the previous version IPv4. 

Furthermore, he European Union fosters del IPv6 to ensure "The goals of the Digital Agenda for Europe and the Digital Single Market Strategy are based on stable and reliable data networks."
See: https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/sites/isa/files/ipv6_framework_for_european_governments_0.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification eases the implementation of the once-only principle.
statement:
The once-only principle is an e-government concept that aims to ensure that citizens, institutions, and companies only have to provide certain standard information to the authorities and administrations once.

The Internet Protocol is a necessary specification for the implementation of the once-only-principle as it allows cross-border communications over the internet.

criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters e-accessibility.
statement: The purpose of IPv6 is not related to  e-accessibility. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable specification.

criterion_description: The specification fosters the secure and trustworthy data exchange between citizens and businesses, and public administrations.
statement:
Internet Protocol Security (IPsec), a protocol providing a network layer security (authentication and encryption), is included as a mandatory feature in the IPv6 specification. IPv6 is more secure than the alternative Internet protocol, IPv4, its previous version.

See: 
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2460

statement: The purpose of IPv6 is not related to the delivery of multilingual services. Therefore this criterion is not applicable to this specification.

criterion_description: The adoption of the standard or specification reduces the administrative burden.
statement:
By allowing communications over the internet, IPv6 contributes to the exchange of information between public administrations therefore, it reduces administrative burden

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2460

statement: The purpose of IPv6 is not related to long term preservation of electronic records. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable to this specification.

statement:
There are several case studies regarding the deployment of IPv6 in Mexico, Greece, USA.

See: 
https://www.internetsociety.org/deploy360/ipv6/case-studies/

criterion_description: The standard or specification can be mapped to the EIRA.
statement:
IPv6 is already associated to EIRA ABBs in the European Library Of Specifications (ELIS). More specifically, IPv6 can define the interoperability aspects of the "Network", "Networking Service", "Private Network" and "Public Network" ABBs of the EIRA Technical View.

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/elis/distribution/eliscataloguev100betaxlsx

criterion_description: Mechanisms to assess conformity of the implementations of the standard or specification (e.g. conformity tests, certifications) are available for free.
statement:
ETSI TTC3+ Conformance test suit is available to test several features of the protocol. 

See: 
http://www.ttcn-3.org/index.php/about/introduction

criterion_description: The standard or specification is recommended by a EU Member State.
statement:
9 Member States are recommending IPv6 in their ICT National Catalogues. 

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

criterion_description: The standard or specification has been selected for its use in a EU cross-border project or initiative after agreed identification and assessment.
statement:
IPv6 has been selected within the TESTA, which provides a secure cross-border data communication network service for public administrations. 
See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/idabc/en/document/2097.html

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in a catalogue of standards at national level.
statement:
The specification is included in 9 Member States' catalogues of recommended specifications. Some examples of Member States including IPv6 on their catalogues are Spain, Sweden, France or Germany. 

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in a catalogue of standards at EU level.
statement:
After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, IPv6 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision and included in the European list of ICT Standards for e-procurement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in an interoperability agreement established between organisations involved in European public service provision.
statement:
After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, IPv6 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision. During the evaluation process, all the Member States are invited to share their doubts. The positive evaluation of IPv6 and its identification is considered an interoperability agreement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

statement:
After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, IPv6 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

statement: The purpose of IPv6 is not related  to the modelling of business processes. Therefore, this criterion is not applicable to the specification.

statement: The information shared by an IPV6 packet,  the smallest message entity exchanged via the Internet Protocol, contains information structured in cross-border reusable data model.

statement: The specification is not related to the publication of public data as open data. Therefore this criterion is not applicable to this specification.

IPv6 is available at Joinup, the European collaborative platform for reusable solutions.

https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/ietf-rfc-2460-1998-internet-protocol-version-6-ipv6-specification/distribution/ietf-rfc-2460-1998-internet-protocol-version-6-ipv6-specification
